chapter: Vascular System and Regional Circulation I

questions.question:
Question 1: The windkessel effect is seen in 
.
questions.explanation:
The windkessel effect is seen in large elastic vessels. The aorta, the pulmonary artery, and their major branches have a large amount of elastin in their 
walls. Hence, they have a high elastic recoil effect. This property of elastic recoil is called 
windkessel effect (windkessel is a German word for the elastic reservoir). This recoil of the vessels that have been stretched during systole helps to propel the blood forward 
during diastole thus maintaining a continuous flow throughout the cardiac cycle.
questions.chapter_heading: Vascular System and Regional Circulation I

questions.question:
Question 2: The greatest total cross-sectional area in the circulatory system is of  
.
questions.explanation:
473 
Sold by @itachibot The greatest total cross-sectional area in the circulatory system is of the capillaries. The total cross-sectional area is minimum for the aorta.
questions.chapter_heading: Vascular System and Regional Circulation I

questions.question: Question 4: Which of the following is not correct regarding capillaries?

options.a: Have a single layer of cells bounding the lumen

questions.explanation: Capillaries contain 5% of the total blood volume.
questions.chapter_heading: Vascular System and Regional Circulation I

questions.question:
Question 5: In the circulatory system, the highest velocity of blood flow is in the  
.
questions.explanation:
In circulatory system, the highest velocity of blood flow is in the aorta. • The velocity of blood flow is inversely proportional to vascular cross-sectional area. 474 
Sold by @itachibot v= velocity F= blood flow through the vessel A=vascular cross-sectional area • Aorta has the least cross sectional area (4.5 cm2) and capillaries have the maximum cross 
sectional area (4500 cm2). Thus, under resting conditions, the velocity is highest in aorta and 
least in capillaries.
questions.chapter_heading: Vascular System and Regional Circulation I

questions.question:
Question 6: The largest compliance in the circulatory system is of  
.
questions.explanation:
The largest compliance in the circulatory system is of veins. Vascular compliance/capacitance is the total quantity of blood that can be stored in a given 
portion of the circulation for each mmHg pressure rise. Vascular Compliance = distensibility X volume. The compliance of a systemic vein is about 24 times that of its corresponding artery because it is 
about 8 times as distensible and has a volume about 3 times as artery (8 × 3 = 24).
questions.chapter_heading: Vascular System and Regional Circulation I

questions.question:
Question 7: Bernoulli’s principle states that 
.

options.a: Sum of kinetic energy of flow and pressure energy is constant
options.b: Low tones produces maximum stimulation at the apex of cochlea
options.c: Magnitude of sensation felt is proportional to the intensity of stimulus
options.d: Force of contraction is proportional to stretch of the cardiac muscle

questions.explanation:
The Bernoulli's theorem states that in a tube or blood vessel, the sum of the kinetic energy of flow 
and pressure energy is constant. Other options: • Option B: Travelling wave theory (Theories of hearing): Low tones produce maximum 
stimulation at the apex of the cochlea. 475 
Sold by @itachibot • Option C: Weber—Fechner law: The magnitude of sensation felt is proportional to the log of the 
intensity of the stimulus. • Option D: Frank—Starling law of the heart: Force of contraction is proportional to stretch of the 
cardiac muscle.
questions.chapter_heading: Vascular System and Regional Circulation I

questions.question: Question 8: The blood flow through a vessel varies directly with
questions.explanation: The blood flow through a vessel varies directly with pressure difference. The blood flow follows Ohm’s law: Where, • F = Blood flow • P = Pressure difference between two ends of the vessel • R = Resistance
questions.chapter_heading: Vascular System and Regional Circulation I

questions.question: Question 9: Which of the following increases turbulence in blood flow?

options.a: Increase in diameter of blood vessel

questions.explanation:
Turbulence in blood flow increases with increase in diameter of blood vessel. The turbulence of flow depends upon Reynold’s number: 476 
Sold by @itachibot Where, v – velocity of flow – cm/sec  – density of blood d – diameter of the vessel  – viscosity of blood in poise Therefore, increase in diameter increases turbulence. Reynold’s num

questions.chapter_heading: Vascular System and Regional Circulation I

questions.question:
Question 10: The tendency for turbulent flow is greatest in  
.
questions.explanation:
The tendency for turbulent flow is greatest in the aorta. The turbulence of flow depends upon Reynold’s number: 477 
Sold by @itachibot v – velocity of flow – cm/sec  – density of blood d – diameter of the vessel  – viscosity of blood in poise In the proximal portions of the aorta and pulmonary artery, Reynold’s number can rise to several 
thousand during the rapid phase of the ejection, which causes considerable turbulence due to the 
following: • High velocity of blood flow • Pulsatile nature of the flow • Sudden change in vessel diameter • Large vessel diameter Reynold’s num 
ber Type of blood flo 
w <2000 
Laminar 2000-3000 
Transitional >3000 
Turbulent
questions.chapter_heading: Vascular System and Regional Circulation I

questions.question: Question 11: The main site of peripheral vascular resistance is
questions.explanation:
The main site of peripheral vascular resistance is precapillary arterioles. Poiseuille—Hagen formula explains that small changes in the calibre of vessels cause large 
changes in total peripheral resistance. 478 
Sold by @itachibot Where, R=resistance =viscosity L=length of the tube r=radius of the tube The resistance varies inversely with the fourth power of radius.
questions.chapter_heading: Vascular System and Regional Circulation I

questions.question:
Question 12: The factor favoring filtration at the arterial end of the capillary bed is  
.

options.b: Increase in hydrostatic pressure of the capillary
options.c: Increase in oncotic pressure of the capillary
options.d: Decrease in oncotic pressure of the interstitium

questions.explanation:
The factor favoring filtration at the arterial end of the capillary bed is the increase in hydrostatic 
pressure of the capillary. The rate of filtration at any point along the capillary bed depends on the balance of the Starling 
forces, which are responsible for fluid movement. Net filtration pressure = (Pc-Pi)-(c- i) where, Pc=capillary hydrostatic pressure Pi=interstitial hydrostatic pressure c=capillary colloidal osmotic pressure i=interstitial colloidal osmotic pressure Glomerular filtration rate = k x NFP where, k= capillary filtration coefficient NFP= Net filtration pressure 479 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Vascular System and Regional Circulation I

questions.question: Question 13: Which of the following factors tends to increase the lymph flow?
questions.explanation:
The factor tend to increase lymph flow is increase in capillary hydrostatic pressure. Since the lymph is derived from interstitial fluid, any factor that increases interstitial fluid 
pressure also increases lymph flow provided, the lymph vessels are functioning normally. The 
factors which increase interstitial fluid pressure include: • Increased capillary hydrostatic pressure • Increased interstitial fluid colloid osmotic pressure • Increased permeability of the capillaries • Decreased plasma colloid osmotic pressure All of the above factors increase the filtration at the capillary-interstitium interface and therefore 
increase the interstitial fluid volume and pressure.
questions.chapter_heading: Vascular System and Regional Circulation I

questions.question:
Question 14: The coronary blood flow is regulated by  
.
questions.explanation:
Coronary blood flow is regulated by adenosine. Blood flow through the coronary system is regulated mostly by local arteriolar vasodilation in 
response to the nutritional needs of cardiac muscle. local metabolism  in O2  breakdown of ATP to form adenosine  vasodilation  local 
coronary blood flow.
questions.chapter_heading: Vascular System and Regional Circulation I

questions.question: Question 15: True about coronary flow during systole is:

options.a: No change in flow with systole.
options.c: Greater decrease in subendocardium than epicardium.
options.d: Greater decrease in epicardium than in subendocardium.

questions.explanation:
The coronary blood flow in systole has a greater decrease in subendocardium than epicardium. The myocardial compression in systole compresses the subendocardial vessels to a greater extent, 
and the force is sufficiently dissipated in the epicardium to permit some flow in this region 
throughout the cardiac cycle.
questions.chapter_heading: Vascular System and Regional Circulation I

questions.question:

Based on the agglutination test shown in the image, the blood group is O positive. As agglutination is present only in 'Rh' and not with 'A' and 'B' hence the blood group is O Rh

questions.chapter_heading: Vascular System and Regional Circulation I

questions.question:
Question 17: Which of the following clotting factors would have decreased gamma carboxyglutamate 
residue in a patient on warfarin therapy?
questions.explanation:
Factor 2 would have decreased gamma carboxyglutamate residue in a patient on warfarin therapy. Activation of coagulation factors II, VII, IX, X is done by carboxylation of their glutamate 
residues. This is done by the enzyme -glutamyl carboxylase with the reduced form of vitamin K 
as a co-factor. This reduced form of vitamin K needs to be constantly recycled back from its oxidized form for the 
reaction to continue. This recycling is done by the enzyme vitamin K epoxide reductase. This 
enzyme is inhibited by warfarin. Hence, warfarin indirectly inhibits the -carboxylation of vitamin K dependent clotting factors 
- Factors II, VII, IX, X by directly inhibiting vitamin K epoxide reductase. Thus leading to 
decreased gamma carboxyglutamate residue in these factors. 481 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Vascular System and Regional Circulation I

questions.question: Question 18: Which of the following has the highest oxygen concentration in fetal circulation?
questions.explanation:
Inferior vena cava has the highest oxygen concentration in fetal circulation. The blood gets oxygenated in the placenta and this passes to the umbilical vein. From the 
umbilical vein, 50% of the blood enters the hepatic circulation and 50% bypasses the liver to enter 
the inferior vena cava. From here, the blood enters the heart via the right atrium. The right atrium 
also receives deoxygenated blood from the superior vena cava. This mixed blood is distributed to 
the body via aorta. Therefore, inferior vena cava has the highest concentration of oxygen in the fetal circulation. 482 
Sold by @itachibot Vascular System and Regional Circulation II
questions.chapter_heading: Vascular System and Regional Circulation I
